Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Community Sourcing Introductory Physics for the Life Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Introductory Physics for Life Science (IPLS) Portal will enhance the education of hundreds of thousands of life science students each year by providing engaging and effective IPLS instructional materials and helping IPLS instructors use these materials. This collaborative effort of the American Association of Physics Teachers and eight colleges and universities, including a community college and a Hispanic-serving institution, will create an open-source, peer-reviewed, and innovatively structured environment for IPLS content. Initially containing materials from multiple NSF-funded research and development projects, the Portal will become a development platform for IPLS curricula. The site will serve as both an archive and a dissemination tool, including a course-building interface for faculty. Instructors will be supported in creating innovative and individualized courses, mixing and matching from multiple sources tuned to their needs, offering a flexible and low-cost alternative to traditional textbooks.

Many of the objectives and features of the project are innovative. Hence, the project also includes research components of four critical and interacting elements: IPLS content, IPLS pedagogy, the organizational structure of the site, including tagging and taxonomy of all elements for appropriate selection to meet the needs of individual users, and the user interface. Three overlapping research teams will carry out this work: the User-Centered Design team, the Instructional Content Design team, and the Community-Building and Professional-Development team. This project focuses on engaging and expanding three communities: (1) physics and biology education researchers, (2) IPLS contributors, and (3) IPLS adopters wanting to use and adapt existing IPLS materials. Merging and expanding the efforts of these communities will occur through a combination of workshops, online support communities, and research to advance the understanding of faculty professional development for IPLS education. The IPLS-Portal infrastructure, once developed, could be used to provide a community-sourcing environment for other STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "Community Sourcing of Introductory Physics for the Life Sciences" project is a collaborative effort by researchers and educators at multiple universities (George Washington University, Mercy College, Swarthmore College, University of Maryland-College Park, Montgomery College, Rockhurst University, University of New Hampshire, and Portland State University) under the leadership of the American Association of Physics Teachers. We built an open-source, peer-reviewed innovatively structured online environment to exchange and disseminating curricular materials and resources for Introductory Physics for the Life Sciences (IPLS) courses. The website, known as the Living Physics Portal (LPP), is available under: https://www.livingphysicsportal.org/.

The intellectual merits of the project lie in the curricular contributions of the collaborating colleges and universities. They bring research-based curricular materials for IPLS courses created for this project or previous, often NSF-supported, projects into a common environment available to physics instructors anywhere. During the project we created additional support material, prepared the curriculum for use by other instructors, and exchanged ideas about each other's curricular resources. We built and tested the usability of the LPP platform during submission, search, download, and use in the classroom.

At Portland State University we prepared pre-health relevant physics lab activities initially developed under NSF grant "Physics in medicine: active learning tools for undergraduate physics courses developed in a joint collaboration of STEM scientists and medical Experts" and multimedia curriculum developed under NSF grants "Multimedia modules for physics instruction in a flipped classroom course for pre-health and life science majors" and "Improving Introductory Physics for Life-Science Students through a Biomedically Relevant Multimedia Curriculum" for the LPP. The curriculum, which is of particular relevance to students pursuing careers in the healthcare field, include the physics involved in topics such as: Pulse Oximetry, Ultrasound imaging, LASIK surgery, Positron Emission Tomography, Magnetic Resonance Imaging, Body Composition Measurement, Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis, Computed Tomography, Physical Therapy, Radiation Therapy, Electrocardiograms, Cardiology, Microscopy, and Endoscopy. We prepared instructors resources, classroom implementation recommendations, and assessment materials to help other instructors with the use of the curriculum. For each topic we identified the relevant life science, physics, mathematics, and other science concepts used in the teaching resource.

 

The broader impacts of the project created a large keyword searchable collection of teaching resources for pre-health and life science introductory physics instruction. Curricular materials from PSU and multiple other institutions can now be more easily found, accessed, and used by other instructors. Feedback from other instructors can lead to further developments of the curriculum.

 

To provide an overview of the overall submissions to the LPP we worked to design and implement features in the LPP that can automatically generate a report showing the number of resources currently hosted by the LPP in the following categories:  1) the subject matter topics (e.g. physics, life sciences and chemistry), 2) the pedagogical approach for which the activity described by the resource is suitable (e.g. peer instruction, SCALE UP, estimation, lab work), 3) the equipment involved (e.g. computers, everyday items, life sciences specialized equipment),  4) the type of resource (e.g. clicker question, homework problem, hands-on activity), 5) the skills practiced (e.g. dimensional analysis, analyzing experimental data, interdisciplinarity), and 6) the mathematics level required (e.g. algebra, trigonometry, calculus). 

At Portland State University, we are currently implementing a new full-year IPLS course sequence. We are drawing from our own curricular materials (shared on the LPP) and resources and ideas from the LPP for these courses. Similarly, the LPP can serve as the starting point for instructors across the country to create an IPLS course that serves the needs at their institution. As the curricular resources on the LPP grow, courses that meet the needs of life science students can be created by more physics instructors without extensive background in the life sciences as a result of this project. With the growing LPP community initiated by this project thousands of IPLS students are impacted at colleges and universities around the country.
